msContents.summary: This abridged manuscript of the Dīvān-i Shams-i Tabrīzī by Jalāl al-Dīn Rūmī contains roughly 600 ghazal lyric poems. While it includes verses not found in standard editions, it also omits stanzaic poems and quatrains typically found in other copies.

msItem.title: Dīvān-i Shams-i Tabrīzī
ديوان شمس تبريزی
msItem.incipit: برگ ۱پ (folio 1b): گر تو بخشی روشنی اي به لقا * رویتو بنماید و گنج لقا.
msItem.explicit: برگ ۳۶۴ر (folio 364a): شمس تبریز رفت و ریزی(؟) گفت * آن خردمند بود آنکه بگفت.

supportDesc.support: Written on medium-weight, tan-coloured straight-grained paper probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent, with ~1.5 mm. between laid lines and few discernible chain lines, externally sized, and polished.
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in pencilled Arabic numerals on the upper-left corners of the a sides by the cataloguer.
supportDesc.collation: Collation undetermined due to tight opening from resewing. Catchwords present at the lower-left corners of the b sides.
supportDesc.condition: Handle with caution. In fair condition, with extensive repairs to the pages in the gutters and fore-edge. Extensive water damage, ink transfer, and also intentional obliteration of prior seals.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 to 2 columns with 15 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Primarily written in black nasta‘līq script.

decoDesc.decoNote: Ruling: Marginal ruling throughout in gold outlined with thin black internal single lines and external double lines, surrounded by a comparatively thick ultramarine blue lines.

physDesc.additions:
Marginalia: Pencilled motes likely in the hand of former own Turner Macan, including several that suggest he considered specific passages for recitations, possibly for teaching or administering examinations that he conducted at Fort William College in Calcutta (Kolkata today) in circa 1823. Inscriptions:
The first right flyleaf a side (f. ia) bears modern pencilled marks with the title at top, followed by a description in neat miniscule followed by a Persian quote appears in the hand of former owner Nathaniel Bland
The second right flyleaf a side (f. ia), top-left, signed T. Macan by former owner Turner Macan, who may have pencilled the Persian quotation beneath a crudly-drawn black geometric decorative design with the title of the work in Persian.
Bookplates: Left paste-down: Bibliotheca Lindesiana with shelfmark 2/I, Bland MSS No. 464.

binding.p: Probably rebound for former owner Turner Macan.

Resewn on three recessed cords, laced into the pasteboards. Edges trimmed and finely spattered in reddish-brown, and European-style, front bead decorative endbands sewn in red and white silk thread at head and tail. Half-bound, tight-backed, in brown speckled calfskin leather, and marbled paper sides featuring pink 'Stormont' over olive green 'Shell' with black veins.
binding.decoNote: Spine panels palleted with double fillet with waved lines on either side, with central quatrefoils. Titled DEWAN SHUMSOODEEN

history.origin: Probably completed in the Indian subcontinent; undated, but probably late 17th to early 18th century.

provenance.p: Subsequently acuired by Turner Macan (1792-1836), Persian translator for the British East India Company, and instructor at Fort William College, who published the first critical edition of the Shāhnāmah of Firdawsī in 1829.

During a visit to Britain in Nov. 1833, Macan evidently sold an unspecified number of manuscripts to scholar Nathaniel Bland (1803–1865) for £91, 3 shillings, and sixpence (see Bland papers, British Library, Add. 30378, no. 199), so the latter may have obtained this volume at that time. However after Macan's death, his family also sold some volumes in Calcutta (Kolkata) through the firm of Jenkins, Low & Co., but another subsequent sale by Evans in London on 12 Dec. 1838 omits this title.
After Bland's death, London Bookseller Bernard Quaritch (1819–1899) sold his oriental manuscripts to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) in 1866.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript handlist by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s and his Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
